name: SNF (Similarity Network Fusion).
description:
SNF is a method that leverages multiple genomic data types (e.g. transcriptome, methylation, etc.) to determine sample-to-sample networks enabling improved clustering and subtype detection. Further information is available at https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.2810
Note that for this version in WebMeV, we require that all input files have the columns/samples ordered in the same manner. For example column k of an expression matrix corresponds to column k of a methylation matrix. We ignore the column/sample lines and assume everything is ordered appropriately. This may change in the future.

input_matrices.description: The input data. SNF can work with multiple data types such as expression, methylation, miRNA expression- essentially any data that can be put into a numeric table. Select as many files as you would like to include. Note that we assume all the files have the same column ordering.
input_matrices.name: Input matrices:

num_neighbors.description: How many neighbors are considered when clustering? The SNF authors recommend a number in the range of 10-30
num_neighbors.name: Neighbors:

alpha.description: The parameter controls the weights in the matrix of sample-to-sample similarities; the authors recommend 0.3-0.8. See paper for further details.
alpha.name: Scaling parameter:

num_clusters.description: The number of patient clusters you expect. After computing the subject-to-subject similarities from all data types, SNF uses spectral clustering to assign the clusters.
num_clusters.name: Number of clusters:
